The 2nd season premiered on May 9, 2017. ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" style="width:65%;" |- ! Actor !! Character !! Role !! Episode |- | [[Aviv Alush]] || Amos Dahari || Baker from [[Bat-Yam]] || 1-10 |- | [[Rotem Sela]] || Noa Hollander || International superstar model || 1-10 |- | [[Mark Ivanir]] || Tzvika Granot || Noa's agent || 1-10 |- | [[Hila Saada]] || Vanessa Maimon || Amos's ex-girlfriend || 1-10 |- | [[Ofer Hayoun]] || Assaf Dahari || Amos's brother || 1-10 |- | [[Nava Medina]] || Amalia Dahari || Amos's mother || 1-10 |- | [[Shani Aviv]] || Merav Dahari || Amos's sister || 1-10 |- | [[Uri Gavriel]] || Avi Dahari || Amos's father || 1-10 |- | [[Yaffa Levi]] || Shosh || Amalia's friend neighbor || 1-8 |- | [[Mitchell Mullen]] || Harry || Famous director || 3-6 |- | [[Jason Lewis (actor)|Jason Lewis]] || Pete Evans || Noa's ex-boyfriend || 1, 10 |- | [[Nigel Meadows]] || Jonathan || Harry's son || 3-5 |- |} ==English subtitled version== An English subtitled version was released online on the Channel 4 website.{{cite web|title=Beauty and the Baker - On Demand - All 4|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/beauty-and-the-baker/on-demand|website=www.channel4.com|accessdate=10 December 2016}} On June 20, 2017 [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] acquired global rights of the first two seasons of the show and will stream them worldwide on [[Amazon Prime Video]].{{cite news|last1=Keslassy|first1=Elsa|title=Amazon Nabs Global Rights to Keshet Hit Show ‘The Baker and the Beauty’|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/global/amazon-prime-video-global-keshet-internationals-baker-and-the-beauty-1202472302/|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=Variety|date=20 June 2017}} ==U.S. adaptation== In November 2018, it was announced that an adaptation of the series was being developed by Dean Georgaris and [[David Frankel]] through Keshet Studios and [[Universal Television]] for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. Georgaris and Frankel are set to write and direct, respectively, and both will executive produce alongside [[Avi Nir]], [[Alon Shtruzman]], [[Peter Traugott]], and Rachel Kaplan.{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/10/baker-and-the-beauty-romantic-comedy-based-on-israeli-format-from-dean-georgaris-david-frankel-set-at-abc-1202485265/|title=‘Baker And The Beauty’ Romantic Comedy Based On Israeli Format Set At ABC From Dean Georgaris, David Frankel & Keshet|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=October 18, 2018|accessdate=November 9, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|3377134}} [[Category:Israeli drama television series]] [[Category:Serial drama television series]] [[Category:2013 Israeli television series debuts]] [[Category:Television programmes on Channel 2 (Israel)]] [[Category:Channel 4]] {{israel-tv-stub}}

{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image | Ship image= | Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship class overview | Builders=Kolomenskiy yard | Operators=Kaukas & Mercury | Class before= | Class after= | Subclasses= | Built range=1911–1917 | In service range= | Total ships building= | Total ships planned=14 | Total ships completed=11 | Total ships cancelled=3 | Total ships active=0 | Total ships laid up= | Total ships lost= | Total ships retired= | Total ships scrapped= | Total ships preserved= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header= | Header caption= | Ship type= | Ship tonnage= | Ship displacement= | Ship length=*{{Convert|92.9|m|ftin|abbr=on}} [[Length overall|o/a]] *{{Convert|89.9|m|ftin|abbr=on}} [[Length between perpendiculars|p/p]] | Ship beam={{Convert|9.8|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | Ship height= | Ship draught={{Convert|2|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | Ship draft= | Ship depth= | Ship decks= | Ship deck clearance= | Ship ramps= | Ship ice class= | Ship power= | Ship propulsion=2 × {{Convert|600|hp|0|abbr=on}} 6-cylinder diesel engines | Ship speed= {{Convert|23|km/h|abbr=on}} | Ship capacity=500 passengers, 320 tons of cargo | Ship crew= | Ship notes= }} |} '''''Borodino'' class motorship''' was a class of [[List of Russian river passenger ships|Russian river passenger ships]].{{cite web |url=http://www.riverships.ru/english/specs/borodino.shtml |title=Series of the Type "Borodino" |work=www.riverships.ru |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318045213/http://www.riverships.ru/english/specs/borodino.shtml |archivedate=18 March 2007 }} The series is named after [[Borodino (village), Mozhaysky District, Moscow Oblast|Borodino]] village, and the ships themselves are notable for their size, power, and use in [[Russo-Japanese War|the Russo-Japanese War]] and the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik Revolution]]. ==Origins== The Borodino class were some of the first screw ships for passengers on the various [[List of rivers of Russia|rivers in Russia]]. The ships were built between 1911 and 1917 at the Kolomenskiy shipyard for Kaukas & Mercury primarily for passenger service, although some also performed postal work. == Specifications == The ships each had a pair of six cylinder [[diesel engine]]s, and had double decks. Capable of carrying 500 passengers and up to 300 tons of cargo, they were not small paddle boats, but large ships, over 300 feet long over 30 feet wide. ==History of the series== During the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik Civil War]], the Borodino class ships were used as troop transports in service with the [[Red Army]]. One of the ships was temporarily the flagship of an ad-hoc war fleet, mostly of other retrofitted river craft and fishing vessels.{{cite journal |title=Ships Monthly |publisher=Waterway Productions Ltd. |volume=18 |issue=3 |page=11}} In [[World War II]] a few of the ships were used to evacuate people and wounded soldiers from [[Stalingrad]], but most were tasked with carrying valuable equipment and material back away from the German front towards the interior of the Soviet Union. After 1960, the remaining ships not destroyed by war were rebuilt and refurbished, and operated by the [[Volga Shipping Company]]. ==Ships== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Built || Original Name || Renamed || Fate |- | 1911 || ''Borodino'' || ''Tovarishch Raskolnikov'' (1939)
''Mikoyan'' (1948) || Scrapped, 1997 |- |rowspan="4" |1912 || ''Krasnoarmeets'' || ''Feldmarshal Kutuzov'' (1918) || Sunk, 1942 |- | ''Pamyat Tovarishch Markina'' || ''Bagration'' (1919) || In Crimea, 2005 |- | ''Semnadtsatyy God'' || ''Dvenadtsatyy God'' (1918)

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} : ''For the king, see: king golopov
{{Aromanians}} '''Caloian''' is a [[rain ritual]] in [[Romania]], similar in some ways to [[Paparuda]]. It is mostly found in [[Wallachia]] (Southern part of Romania). The origin of this ritual, as many other local popular beliefs and practices, precedes the spreading of Christianity, although it was in time associated with the period of the Orthodox Easter.
The ritual is celebrated in early spring as a fertilization ritual, or whenever around the year during the time of severe drought or excessive rain. Young girls make one to several clay dolls, resembling male figures, most important being either "Father of the Sun" or the "Mother of the Rain", depending on the purpose of the ritual. This doll is dressed in common clothes, placed on a wooden board or in an improvised tree-bark coffin, ornamented with flowers and so pursuits a mock-up of the traditional burial ritual, officiated by children. The suite marches through crop fields, around water courses and wells until the "caloian" gets to be buried. After three days, the "caloian" is unearthed, returned to the village and mourned again until it is finally set loose to float on the water of a river, lake or thrown into a well. This ceremony being ended, the young girls who had attained the ceremony were baking a special cake called "ghismán" or "ghizman" (from [[Ghetsemane]], as this ritual was often related to the Easter period) which was shared with the rest of the children.
==See also== * [[German (mythology)]]
[[Category:Romanian folklore]] [[Category:Romanian traditions]] [[Category:Rainmaking (ritual)]]
{{Romania-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Anarchism sidebar}} The '''Confédération Générale du Travail-Syndicaliste Révolutionnaire''' (General Confederation of Revolutionary Trade Unions) was a [[trade union]] federation in [[France]] founded in 1926 by [[Pierre Besnard]] with the help of the Spanish [[Confederación Nacional del Trabajo|CNT]]. It was affiliated to the [[International Workers' Association]].<ref>Facing the Enemy: A History of Anarchist Organization from Proudhon to May 1968, Alexandre Skirda, Tr. Paul Sharkey, AK Press, 2002, {{ISBN|1-902593-19-7}}, {{ISBN|978-1-902593-19-7}}, page 117.</ref>
It was an anarchist split from the [[Confédération générale du travail unitaire]] (CGT-U)<ref>Syndicalism and the transition to communism: an international comparative analysis, Ralph Darlington, Ed. Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., 2008, {{ISBN|0-7546-3617-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7546-3617-5}}, page 172</ref> and was made illegal in 1939.
== Theoretical Legacy ==
Its legacy comprises the [[charter of Lyons]], which founded anti-political syndicalism.
== Syndicalist Activity == It took part in the major struggles of its time, like [[anti-colonialism]], the strikes of June 1936 in France, or the support to Spanish Republicans during the [[Spanish Civil War]]<ref>Durruti in the Spanish revolution, Abel Paz, José Luis Gutiérrez Molina, Chuck Morse, Tr. Chuck Morse, AK Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-904859-50-X}}, 9781904859505, page 134.</ref> and the resistance to the Nazis.
The CGT-SR actively opposed [[French colonialism]], both in [[Algeria]] and in [[France]]. For the occasion of the centenary of the colonisation of Algeria, in 1930, a declaration denouncing colonialism was signed by the [[Union Anarchiste]], the CGT-SR and the [[Association des Fédéralistes Anarchistes]].
== Famous members ==
*[[Pierre Besnard]] *[[Victor Giraud]] *[[Paul Lapeyre]] *[[Sail Mohamed]] (1894–1953) *[[Adrien Perrissaguet]] *[[Vincent Joseph]] (1920- ) *[[Antoine Turmo]]
==References==
<references />
== See also == {{Portal|Organized labour}} *[[Anarchism in France]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox union |name= EuroCOP |country= [[Europe]] |affiliation= [[European Trade Union Confederation|ETUC]] |members= 600,000 |full_name= European Confederation of Police |native_name= |image=[[Image:EuroCOP logo.jpg|150px]] |founded= 2002 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]], [[Luxembourg]] |people= [[Anna Neilberg]], chairman |website= [http://www.eurocop-police.org/ eurocop-police.org] |footnotes= }} The '''European Confederation of Police''' ('''EuroCOP''') is the [[umbrella organization]] of 33 trade unions from 26 European countries, which represent a total of more than 500,000 police officers. It was founded in 2002 at a conference in [[Roskilde]], [[Denmark]], emerging from the [[Union Internationale des Syndicats de Police]] (UISP), which had existed since 1953. It was created in order to enable further organizations, particularly ones from the [[United Kingdom]], to join. The union's headquarters is in [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]].
EuroCOP represents its members in European matters and at [[European Union]] institutions. For example, the union has an observer status at the [[Council of Europe]]. Its goals include enhancing the efficiency of police work under democratic control, the creation of norms for the qualifications of police employees, the preservation of the civil status of police officers, and the prevention of the [[privatization]] of police duties. One example of a current mission of EuroCOP has been to push the [[Spain|Spanish]] government to follow its election promise to completely [[militarization|de-militarize]] the [[Guardia Civil]].
The organization should not be confused with the idea of "Euro-Cops", [[EUROPOL]] police officers, whose jurisdiction would reach into all of Europe.
== Background == The European Confederation of Police (EuroCOP) is an organization made up of 33 trade unions from 26 European Countries, which includes more than 500,000 police officers. The EuroCOP was founded in a conference in 2002 in Roskilde, Denmark as a revision to the precious Union Internationale des Syndicats de Police (UISP), which had existed since 1953. The organization was created to allow police organizations from the United Kingdom to join. EuroCOP are members of the European Union Institutions, which allows the union to have a say in the council of Europe. The goal is to enhance the police work under democratic control, to prevent private investor of police duties, and to create norms for the police employees.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurocop.org/about-eurocop/|title=EuroCOP: About EUROCOP|last=EuroCop|website=www.eurocop.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref>
== No. 83/2012 European Confederation of Police (EUROCOP) v. Ireland == EuroCOP filled a complaint against Ireland on June 7, 2012; dealing with the fact that police representative associations in Ireland do not have full trade union rights including the right to join an umbrella organisation. An umbrella organization is an association of institutions, who work together formally to coordinate activities or pool resources. The EuroCOP requested that Ireland grants complete full trade union rights for the police representations in Ireland. Meaning, that the police representative associations are kept out of the overall national negotiations that ICTU conduct on behalf of their members, such as those on salaries in the public service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurocop.org|title=EuroCOP: EuroCOP|last=EuroCop|website=www.eurocop.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref>
== EuroCop mission == EuroCOP has been fighting to try and get attention and promote four main groups.
~ a social Europe for the police
~ Internal Security for the Police
~ Safety for the Police
~ Solidarity and Network building
By 2020, EuroCOP plans on working together in the environment of equality, safety and support and providing the rights, rescue and training to keep the European citizens safe and secure for the future ahead.
EuroCOP has a missions to set of three strategies to guide our actions in the years to come.
~ Raising EuroCOP’s profile
~ Building EU policy that supports European police officers
~ Establishing policing best practice<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurocop.org/about-us/our-mission/|title=EuroCOP: Our Mission|last=EuroCop|website=www.eurocop.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref>
== Health and Safety == The EU has a certain health and safety policy for all of their workers. Here are the policies:
* EuroCOP strongly encourages further discussion of sector specific legislative initiatives on the health and safety rights of police officers at the EU level. It is crucial that the appropriate working conditions are in place to reduce work-related illnesses as much as possible. * Working conditions can be varied and imbalanced across the EU. Increasingly, police officers are not provided with the same health and safety rights as other European workers. EuroCOP believes that the main driver to redress this imbalance needs to be political will and the proper implementation of current EU health and safety legislation. * EuroCOP stresses the need for the health and safety of police officers to be addressed at the political level to enable information-sharing and best practices on the prevention of violence against law enforcement officers and the reduction of their exposure to extreme situations, allowing them to perform their duties safely. The capabilities of European police forces depend to a large extent on the appropriate working conditions. * EuroCOP calls on EU policymakers to recognize the particularities of police work and to ensure that police officers are provided with the appropriate working conditions (including equipment and training) to carry out their duties and to keep citizens and themselves safe and healthy. * EuroCOP believes that it is of utmost importance for injured police officers have equal access to the necessary medical and psychological support across the EU Member States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurocop.org/eupolicyactivities/healthandsafety/|title=EuroCOP: Health and Safety|last=EuroCop|website=www.eurocop.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref>
== Social Rights == Over the last couple years, European police have had their rights been slowly taken away. The only way police officers can fully enjoy the benefits of their rights, such as just conditions of work and fair pay, it is important that all obstacles inhibit the exercise of police union rights and the right to freedom of expression are removed. EuroCOP is working with European policymakers to address these issues and raise awareness about the different national conditions for law enforcement employees and their organizations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurocop.org/eupolicyactivities/socialrights/|title=EuroCOP: Social Rights|last=EuroCop|website=www.eurocop.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref>
==Member organizations== {{div col|colwidth=40em}} *[[Association of Garda Sergeants and Inspectors]] ([[Ireland]]) *[[Association Syndicale Autonome des Personnels de la Police d'Etat de Monaco]] ([[Monaco]]) *[[British Transport Police Federation]] ([[United Kingdom]]) *[[Confederazione Sindacale Autonoma di Polizia]] (Italy; observer) *[[ELA / ERTZAINTZA]] ([[Spain]]) *[[Federación de Sindicatos de Policía]] (Spain) *[[Garda Representative Association]] (Ireland) *[[Landssamband Lögreglumanna]] ([[Iceland]]) *[[Latvijas Apvienotā Policistu arodbiedrība]] ([[Latvia]]; associate member) *[[Natzionalen Poltzeyski Syndicat]] ([[Bulgaria]]; observer) *[[Odborovy zväz Policie vsr]] ([[Slovakia]]) *[[Österreichische Polizeigewerkschaft]] ([[Austria]]; observer) *[[Panhellenic Federation of Police]] ([[Greece]]) *[[Police Federation for Northern Ireland]] (United Kingdom) *[[Policijski Sindikat Slovenije]] ([[Slovenia]]) *[[Norwegian Police Federation]] ([[Norway]]) *[[Politiforbundet i Danmark]] ([[Denmark]]) *[[Scottish Police Federation]] (United Kingdom) *[[Sindicatul Naţional al Poliţiştilor şi Personalului Contractual România]] ([[Romania]]) *[[SIULP]] ([[Italy]]) *[[SLFP-Police/VSOA-Politie]] ([[Belgium]]) *[[SNPS/NSPV]] (Belgium) *[[SPC-CCOO Catalunya]] (Spain) *[[Suomen Poliisijarjestöjen Liito]] ([[Finland]]) *[[Swedish Police Union|Polisförbundet]] ([[Sweden]]) *[[Syndicat National de la Police Grand-Ducale Luxembourg]] ([[Luxembourg]]) *[[Verband Schweizerischer Polizeibeamter]] ([[Switzerland]]) *[[Nezávislý odborový svaz Policie České republiky (NOSP)]] ([[Czech Republic]]) *[[Sindicato Nacional da Policia (SINAPOL)]] ([[Portugal]]) *[[Niezalezny Samorzadny Zwiazek Zawodowy Policjantów (NSZZP)]] ([[Poland; observer]]) *[[Lietuvos VRS Respublikiné Profesiné Sajvisited (LPTU)]] ([[Lithuania]]) *[[Vereniging van Middelbare en Hogere Politieambtenaren (VMHP)]] ([[Netherlands]]) {{div col end}}

{{Infobox Union| |name= SuPer |country= [[Finland]] |affiliation= [[Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees|STTK]] |members= 63,000 |full_name= Finnish Union of Practical Nurses |native_name= Suomen lähi- ja perushoitajaliitto
Finlands närvårdar- och primärskötarförbund |image= [[Image:SuPer logo.png|175px]] |founded= 1948 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Helsinki]], Finland |people= |website= [http://www.superliitto.fi/?lang=en www.superliitto.fi] |footnotes= }} The '''Finnish Union of Practical Nurses''' (SuPer, {{lang-fi|Suomen lähi- ja perushoitajaliitto SuPer}}, {{lang-sv|Finlands närvårdar- och primärskötarförbund SuPer}}) is a [[trade union]] in [[Finland]]. It has a membership of over 63,000 and is affiliated with the [[Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees]]. ==References== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }} ==External links== *[http://www.superliitto.fi/?lang=en www.superliitto.fi] {{Portal|Organized labour|Nursing}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Finnish Union Of Practical Nurses}} [[Category:Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees]] [[Category:Nursing organizations]] [[Category:Trade unions in Finland]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1948]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations in Finland]] {{Europe-trade-union-stub}} {{Finland-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''French Intellectual Property Code''' ('''IPC'''; [[French language|French]]: ''Code de la propriété intellectuelle''), is a corpus of law relating to intellectual and industrial property. It was formalised by Law No 92-597 of 1 July 1992, replacing earlier laws relating to [[industrial property]] and [[literary property|artistic and literary property]].
The code is frequently modified: two major modifications are known as the [[DADVSI law]] and the [[HADOPI law]].
==See also== *[[French copyright law]]
==External links== * {{fr-icon}} [http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCode.do?cidTexte=LEGITEXT000006069414&dateTexte=20080129 Text of the code on Légifrance]
[[Category:French intellectual property law]] [[Category:Intellectual property law]]
{{Europe-law-stub}}

Sarajevo | parent = | key people = Elvir Švrakić | slogan = Hayat PLUS | motto = | country = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] | language = [[Bosnian language]] | broadcast area = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
and Worldwide | affiliates = | headquarters = Jošanička 55 [[Vogošća]]
(WOG Centar) | former names = NTV Hayat SAT
(1 November 2002 - 1 January 2006) | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = [[Hayat TV (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|Hayat TV]]
[[Hayatovci]]
[[Hayat Music]]
[[Hayat Folk]] | timeshift names = | website = [http://www.hayat.ba/hayat-plus.php www.hayat.ba/plus] | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = Eutelsat 16A | sat chan 1 = Eutelsat W3, 16E,(H), 11.262 MHz,FEC: 2/3, | cable serv 1 = [[Telinea]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 073 | cable serv 2 = [[M&H Company]] Digital | cable chan 2 = Channel 007 | cable serv 3 = [[Telemach.si]] Slovenia | cable chan 3 = Channel 034 | cable serv 4 = [[H1 Telekom]] Croatia | cable chan 4 = Channel 086 | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = [[Moja TV]] | iptv chan 1 = Channel 075 | iptv serv 2 = [[SUPER TV (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|SUPER TV]] | iptv chan 2 = Channel 006 | iptv serv 3 = [[HOME.TV (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|HOME.TV]] | iptv chan 3 = Channel 008 | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }} '''Hayat Plus''' or '''Hayat PLUS''' is a [[Bosnia]]n satellite television channel. It is operated by [[Hayat TV (Bosnia and Herzegovina)|Hayat TV]]. The headquarters of TV channel is located in [[Vogošća]] (near [[Sarajevo]]). The program is produced in [[Bosnian language]] and [[television program|programming]] is dedicated to [[Bosnian diaspora]]. The program is broadcast since 2002 (formerly known as NTV Hayat SAT).{{cite web|title= NTV Hayat Satelit|url=http://www.ntvhayat.com|website=www.ntvhayat.com|publisher=www.ntvhayat.com|accessdate=29 November 2015 |archivedate=2004-08-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040804171943/http://www.ntvhayat.com/satelit/satelitindex.htm|language=Bosnian}} The program consists of a variety of reportages about the life of Bosnians in Australia, the United States and Europe and it is made by direct contact with people in the Diaspora. The most significant TV shows from the Hayat TV production are adjusted for people in other time zones, without commercials and interruptions. ''Hayat Plus'' cooperates with local [[Television in Bosnia and Herzegovina|TV stations]] in BiH and often broadcast their weekly chronicle.{{cite web|title=Hayat PLUS|url=http://www.hayat.ba/hayat-plus.php|website=www.hayat.ba|publisher=www.hayat.ba|accessdate=29 November 2015|language=Bosnian}} '''Hayat Plus''' is available via [[Cable television|cable systems]] throughout the [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|former Yugoslavia]] ([[Balkan|Balkan countries]]).{{cite web|title=www.tvprofil.net|url=http://tvprofil.net/kanali/kanal/hayat-plus|website=www.tvprofil.net|accessdate=29 November 2015|language=Croatian}} Hayat Plus is part of special ''Hayat TV package'' (with Hayat TV, [[Hayatovci]], [[Hayat Music]] and [[Hayat Folk]]). Worldwide channel is available via [[Eutelsat]] satellite provider. ==Programmes== [[File:Tuzla unrest 2014-02-07 file 24.JPG|thumbnail|A Hayat TV reporter outside the burning Government Building of Tuzla Canton]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.hayat.ba Official website www.hayat.ba] * [http://www.rak.ba Communications Regulatory Agency of Bosnia and Herzegovina] [[Category:Television in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2002]] [[Category:Satellite television]]

revision.text:
{{About||discussion of the effect of the Kosovo secession on international relations|International recognition of Kosovo|discussion over the legality of the Kosovo secession|Political status of Kosovo}} {{update|date=May 2015}} [[File:Kosovo rep en.png|right|thumb|250px|Map of the Republic of Kosovo]] The [[Assembly of Kosovo]], then a province of [[Serbia]] under transitional UN administration ([[UNMIK]]), approved a [[2008 Kosovo declaration of independence|declaration of independence]] on 17 February 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7249034.stm |title=Kosovo MPs proclaim independence |publisher=BBC News Online |date=2008-02-16 |accessdate=2009-04-09 }}</ref> [[Kosovo]] was soon recognized as a [[sovereign state]] by the [[United States]], [[Turkey]], [[Albania]], [[Austria]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[France]], the [[United Kingdom]], the [[Republic of China|Republic of China (Taiwan)]], and others.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2008/02/20/2003402059 |title=Taiwan officially recognizes Kosovo |publisher=[[Taipei Times]] |author=Hsu, Jenny W |date=2008-02-20 |accessdate=2008-05-13}}</ref> This triggered an international debate over whether Kosovo's [[unilateral declaration of independence]] had set a [[precedent]] in [[international law]] that could apply to other separatist movements, or whether it is a [[sui generis|special case]].<ref name="prospect-magazine.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.prospect-magazine.co.uk/article_details.php?id=10128 |title=The Kosovo Precedent |publisher=Prospect Magazine |date=April 2008 |accessdate=2009-04-13}}</ref> The recognition of Kosovo's independence by 110 out of {{UNnum}} UN states, according to many sources, has given fresh impetus to other separatist movements.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/la-oe-ash21feb21,0,6880108.story |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=2008-02-21 |author=Timothy Garton Ash |accessdate=2009-04-09 |title=The Kosovo precedent}}</ref>
There is an estimation that a group of between 70 and 200 unrecognized nations and organizations use the Kosovo precedent to achieve their goals.<ref name="JovanovicJovanović2013">{{cite book|last1=Jovanovic|first1=Miroslav N.|last2=Jovanović|first2=Miroslav N.|title=The Economics of European Integration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gqU2BRILq_4C&pg=PA929|date=1 January 2013|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-0-85793-398-0|page=929|quote=The Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organisation, a group of some 70 members from Abkhazia over Kurdistan to Zanzibar is and will be using the Kosovo precedent to pursue its objectives.}}</ref> [[Abkhazia]] and [[South Ossetia]] renewed their calls for the recognition of their [[sovereignty]]. Kosovo's independence also led to increased tensions in [[Bosnia-Herzegovina]], where the [[Republika Srpska]] vetoed recognising Kosovo, and threatened to declare independence themselves.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.javno.com/en/world/clanak.php?id=125837 |publisher=Javno |title=Bosnian Serbs Threaten Secession Over Kosovo |date=2008-02-22 |accessdate=2009-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408032847/http://www.javno.com/en/world/clanak.php?id=125837 |archivedate=2008-04-08 |df= }}</ref> The [[Republic of Crimea]] proclaimed its independence from [[Ukraine]] on 11 March 2014, citing the Kosovo precedent, and was [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexed by the Russian Federation]] a week later.
==Arguments==
===Kosovo does not establish a precedent===
Some leaders argue that the Kosovo situation is unique and does not establish a precedent.
In a statement issued 19 February 2008 the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] argued every territorial conflict is unique. It said Kosovo's unilateral independence cannot be used by other states to resolve disputes.<ref name="usstate">{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax.ru/e/B/politics/28.html?id_issue=11972248 |title=Kosovo autonomy is no precedent for other territorial conflicts - U.S. |publisher=[[Interfax]] (Russia) |date=2008-02-20 |accessdate=2008-02-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226080432/http://www.interfax.ru/e/B/politics/28.html?id_issue=11972248 |archivedate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> When asked about the Kosovo's independence in reference to recognition of South Ossetia, [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Condoleezza Rice]] dismissed it and said, "we've been very clear that Kosovo is ''[[sui generis]]'' and that that is because of the special circumstances out of which the breakup of Yugoslavia came. The special circumstances of the aggression of the Milosevic forces against Kosovars, particularly Albanian Kosovars, and it’s a special circumstance."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=17273|title=U.S Rules Out Recognising S.Ossetia|publisher=Civil Georgia ([[Tbilisi]])|date=2008-03-06|accessdate=2008-03-09 }}</ref>
[[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] [[Ban Ki-Moon]] in an interview for [[Interfax]] news agency said "Each situation needs to be examined based on its unique circumstances," and said Kosovo was a "highly distinctive situation" because of the intervention of the international community. At the same time he emphasised that recognition is left up to [[List of United Nations member states|UN member states]] and is not decided by the [[United Nations Secretariat|Secretariat]] or the Secretary-General.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax.com/17/373003/Interview.aspx |title=UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon: I wish to note that Kosovo is a highly distinctive situation |publisher=[[Interfax]] (Russia) |accessdate=2008-03-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314204124/http://www.interfax.com/17/373003/Interview.aspx |archivedate=2008-03-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Kosovo establishes a useful precedent===
Some argue that Kosovo establishes a precedent for other people who wish to secede.
*[[Daniel Turp]], a member of the pro-[[Quebec sovereignty movement|Quebec sovereignty]] [[Parti Québécois]] who sits in the [[National Assembly of Quebec]], said "Recognition [of Kosovo] sets the stage for Ottawa to eventually recognize an independent Quebec"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2008/03/18/canada-kosovo.html |title=Canada recognizes Kosovo, Serbia pulls ambassador |publisher=CBC |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2009-04-07}}</ref> *[[László Tőkés]], an [[Hungarians in Romania|ethnic Hungarian]] from [[Romania]] who is a [[member of the European Parliament]] for [[Hungary]], said Kosovo is a "model for the Romanian region of [[Transylvania]]".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=10&nav_id=48330 |title = Kosovo model for Transylvania |publisher = B92 (Belgrade) |date = 2008-03-10 |accessdate = 2009-04-07 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080311051709/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=10&nav_id=48330 |archivedate = 2008-03-11 |df = }}</ref> *[[Yasser Abed Rabbo]], a member of the [[Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization]] and the Palestinian negotiating team, said that if the United States and the majority of the European Union "have embraced the independence of Kosovo, why shouldn’t this happen with Palestine as well?"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brusselsjournal.com/node/3039 |title=The Kosovo Precedent |publisher=The Brussels Journal |accessdate=2009-04-07}}</ref> *Igor Smirnov, the leader of [[Transnistria]], a predominantly Russian and Ukrainian separatist republic in what is internationally recognised to be eastern [[Moldova]], said "For us, the Kosovo precedent is an important ... factor."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20071227/94383187.html |title=Transdnestr deserves independence more than Kosovo - leader |publisher=[[RIA Novosti]] |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2009-04-07}}</ref>
===Kosovo establishes a dangerous precedent=== A number of political leaders have voiced their belief that the independence of Kosovo will create a dangerous precedent for other separatist movements.
*Russian President Vladimir Putin described the declaration of independence by Kosovo as a "terrible precedent that will come back to hit the West in the face".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/putin-calls-kosovo-independence-terrible-precedent/2008/02/23/1203467431503.html|title=Putin calls Kosovo independence 'terrible precedent' - World - smh.com.au|website=www.smh.com.au}}</ref> Russian Defence Minister [[Sergei Ivanov]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sputniknews.com/world/2007020960462021/|title=Kosovo independence will open up Pandora's box - Russia's Ivanov|first=|last=Sputnik|website=sputniknews.com}}</ref> and Russian diplomat [[Konstantin Kosachev]] said that granting Kosovo independence would open [[wikt:Pandora's box|Pandora's box]].<ref name="b92.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2017&mm=10&dd=03&nav_category=78&nav_id=1309933|title="Kada su priznali Kosovo – otvorili su Pandorinu kutiju"|publisher=}}</ref> *Argentine Foreign Minister [[Jorge Taiana]]: "Recognizing Kosovo's independence ... would set a dangerous precedent against the national claim to recover sovereignty over the [[Falkland Islands|Malvinas islands]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2008/02/20/elpais/p-00701.htm |title=Por las Malvinas, el Gobierno decidió no reconocer a Kosovo |publisher=Clarin.com |date=2008-02-20 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> *The Sri Lankan foreign ministry said Kosovo "could set an unmanageable precedent in the conduct of international relations, the established global order of sovereign states and could thus pose a grave threat to international peace and security."<ref>[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gYnbOs-96E8psUI9a2tBzqfiD87A China 'concerned', Australia backs Kosovo split] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516083806/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gYnbOs-96E8psUI9a2tBzqfiD87A |date=2008-05-16 }}, ''[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]'', February 18</ref> *Czech Republic President [[Václav Klaus]]: "For me Kosovo is, above all, a precedent. We’ve opened a Pandora’s Box in Europe that could have disastrous consequences."<ref>[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=11&nav_id=48353 Czech, Slovak presidents: Kosovo sets precedent] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607010401/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=11&nav_id=48353 |date=2011-06-07 }}, ''[[b92]]'', March 11, 2008</ref> *The Indian Ambassador to Serbia Ajay Swarup: Kosovo "can set a very dangerous precedent for similar cases around the world".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=31&nav_id=48973 |title=Ambassador: India's Kosovo stand consistent |publisher=B92.net |date=2008-03-31 |accessdate=2010-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607012953/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=31&nav_id=48973 |archivedate=2011-06-07 |df= }}</ref> *President [[Amadou Toumani Touré]] of Mali: "International norms must be respected because their abuse and the violation of territorial integrity could threaten a series of countries with a similar problem."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kosovocompromise.com/cms/item/topic/en.html?view=story&id=679&sectionId=1 |title=New governments of Spain and Cyprus will refuse Kosovo recognition |publisher=Kosovocompromise.com |date=2008-03-11 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> *Slovakian Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]]: Kosovo may become a dangerous precedent to be followed by separatists in other regions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.trend.az/index.shtml?show=news&newsid=1137807&lang=EN |title=World’s Reaction to Declaration of Kosovo’s Independence |publisher=News.trend.az |date= |accessdate=2010-04-28 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *Tajikistan Foreign Minister Asomudin Saidov: "This precedent may result in other peoples also demanding territorial independence."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afn.by/news/view.asp?newsid=95911 |title=Таджикистан не признает независимость Косово и считает ее опасной для Европы |publisher=Afn.by |date=2008-02-19 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> *Vietnam's Ambassador to the United Nations Le Luong Minh: "By creating a dangerous precedent, this development has negative implications for international peace and stability,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-02/19/content_7629471.htm|title=UNSC debates Kosovo in emergency session|publisher=}}</ref>
To minimize a serious influence of Kosovo Precedent to the solution of other conflicts, the [[OSCE]] Parliamentary Assembly held in Kiev in July 2007 issued a warning that ''"solution of certain conflicts should not be used as a model for the solution of other conflicts"''.<ref name="Aydın2011">{{cite book|last=Aydın|first=Mustafa|authorlink=Mustafa Aydın|title=Non-traditional Security Threats and Regional Cooperation in the Southern Caucasus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TSGVSbrH1_gC&pg=PA234|year=2011|publisher=IOS Press|isbn=978-1-60750-683-6|page=234|quote=The influence of the Kosovo precedent is so serious that the declaration of the summit of the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly in Kyiv on 9 July 2007 contained a warning that solution of certain conflicts should not be used as a model for the...}}</ref>
===Position of the Russian Federation=== {{See also|Frozen conflict}} Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] stated in 2008: "Our position is extremely clear. Any resolution on Kosovo should be approved by both sides. It is also clear that any resolution on Kosovo will definitely set a precedent in international practice." Analysts have taken this as meaning the Russian Federation would come out for the independence of de facto independent breakaway regions in the [[former Soviet Union]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n131709|title=Putin says Kosovo resolution would set precedent|publisher=FOCUS Information Agency|date=2008-01-17|accessdate=2008-01-18}}</ref>
[[Sergei Mironov]], the chairman of [[Federation Council of Russia|Russia's upper house of parliament]] stated in December 2007, "In case of the unilateral recognition of the independence of Kosovo, Russia will be entitled to change its approach to the so-called unrecognised republics in the post-soviet regions - South Ossetia, Abkhazia and Pridnestrovie." He went on to state "In case of such a recognition of Kosovo, Russia will be able to say that it is free in its approach, including towards the so-called unrecognised republics of [[Abkhazia]], [[South Ossetia]], the [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]] and [[Transnistria]]."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tiraspoltimes.com/node/1501|title=Russia ready to recognize Pridnestrovie if Kosovo gets independence|publisher=[[The Tiraspol Times]] (Transnistria) |date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28 }}</ref>
Immediately following Kosovo's declaration of independence the Russian officials appeared to soften their position, with Boris Gryzlov stating only that Moscow should “reshape its relations with self-proclaimed republics” which according to news reports could mean lifting the economic embargo on the regions.<ref name="separatist">{{cite news|url=http://www.messenger.com.ge/issues/1550_february_20_2008/1550_kosovo.html|title=Separatist leaders give no indication of imminent recognition from Moscow|publisher=The Messenger|date=2008-02-20|accessdate=2008-02-20 }}</ref>
On 13 March 2008, following a hearing on the unrecognised republics, the Russian [[State Duma|Duma]] Committee for CIS recommended an upgrading of relations with Abkhazia, Transnistria, the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic and South Ossetia - including the possibility of recognition. Other recommendations included or reported include:
* the establishment of diplomatic missions in the regions, with the foreign ministry to decide whether they are consulates or another type of mission * a removal of import duties on goods created by businesses with Russian shareholders in the regions * increased humanitarian and economic assistance for Russian passport-holders in the regions
Alexei Ostrovsky, chairman of the lower house's committee on former Soviet affairs said at the parliamentary hearing, "The world community should understand that from now on the resolution of conflicts in the ex-Soviet area cannot be seen in any other context from that of Kosovo." <ref name="afp">{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hagoFjy_a2eH2-_rIyu5skFw1zfw |title=Russian lawmakers call for missions in Georgian rebel regions |publisher=[[Agence France Presse]] (Paris) |date=2008-03-13 |accessdate=2008-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706104548/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hagoFjy_a2eH2-_rIyu5skFw1zfw |archivedate=2008-07-06 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.javno.com/en/world/clanak.php?id=131742 |title=Russia Seeks to Deepen Links With Rebel Regions |publisher=Javno ([[Zagreb]]) |date=2008-03-13 |accessdate=2008-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080902083212/http://www.javno.com/en/world/clanak.php?id=131742 |archivedate=2008-09-02 |df= }}</ref> Participation of the breakaway republics in international organisations and forums was also mentioned in a press release before the hearings.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.trendaz.com/index.shtml?show=news&newsid=1155884&lang=EN |title= Russia Intends to Open its Representations in Unrecognized Republics|publisher= Trend News Agency|date=2008-03-13|accessdate=2008-03-13}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The ''[[Nezavisimaya Gazeta]]'' daily described the hearing as "the launch of a procedure of recognition". The committee recommendations were set to go to a vote a week after the hearing. Russian Deputy Foreign Minister [[Grigory Karasin]] said the ministry would "look carefully at all the recommendations" but that Russian policy remained unchanged.<ref name="afp" />
Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] stated in 2008: "A precedent is objectively created not just for South Ossetia and Abkhazia but also for an estimated 200 territories around the world. If someone is allowed to do something, many others will expect similar treatment."<ref>[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=01&dd=23&nav_id=47173 Kosovo precedent for 200 territories—Lavrov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226060249/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=01&dd=23&nav_id=47173 |date=2008-02-26 }}, ''[[Tanjug]]/[[B92]]'', January 23, 2008</ref> Chairman of Foreign Affairs Committee [[Mikhail Margelov]] said the precedent set by Kosovo "will inspire separatists not only in Europe, but in the Middle East as well."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kommersant.com/p-12061/r_527/Kosovo_independence/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302065604/http://www.kommersant.com/p-12061/r_527/Kosovo_independence/ |archivedate=2008-03-02 |df= }} Russia Will Have Its Eye on Those Who Recognize Kosovo, [[Kommersant]], February 17, 2008</ref>
In 2014 Russia recognized Crimean independence, but not Kosovo.<ref> http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/similar-crimea-kosovo-22971703 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323232216/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/similar-crimea-kosovo-22971703 |date=March 23, 2014 }}</ref>
== Events influenced == === Ukraine and Republic of Crimea === [[File:Crimea republic map 2.png|thumb|Map of [[Crimea]], including the [[Sevastopol]] region which was included in the independence declaration on 11 March 2014.]] The annexation of Ukrainian [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]] by Russia was based on citing the Kosovo precedent in the beginning of the declaration itself.<ref>{{cite news|title=Citing Kosovo precedent, Crimea's parliament declares independence from Ukraine ahead of referendum|url=http://www.sott.net/article/275441-Citing-Kosovo-precedent-Crimeas-parliament-declares-independence-from-Ukraine-ahead-of-referendum|accessdate=12 March 2014|agency=RT|quote="We, the members of the parliament of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea and the Sevastopol City Council, with regard to the charter of the United Nations and a whole range of other international documents and taking into consideration the confirmation of the status of Kosovo by the United Nations International Court of Justice on July 22, 2010, which says that unilateral declaration of independence by a part of the country doesn't violate any international norms, make this decision," says the text of the declaration, which was published by the Crimean media.}}</ref>
Czech president [[Milos Zeman]] called the international community's recognition of Kosovo independence and protest over [[Crimean annexation]] as '[[double standards]]'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Czech president sees Kosovo-Crimea double standards|publisher=B92|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/world.php?yyyy=2017&mm=10&dd=06&nav_id=102495}}</ref>
===Georgia, Abkhazia and South Ossetia=== [[File:Georgia high detail map.png|thumb|left|300px|Map of Georgia showing the autonomous republics of Abkhazia (de facto independent) and Adjaria, and the de facto independent region of South Ossetia.]] EU High Representative for Common Foreign and Security Policy [[Javier Solana]] has expressed concern that Kosovo's campaign for independence could set a precedent for [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]'s breakaway regions of [[South Ossetia]] and [[Abkhazia]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Lobjakas |first=Ahto |url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2006/10/8748c1ca-a82c-444b-b2a9-df357251aa54.html |title=Georgia: Solana Fears Kosovo 'Precedent' For Abkhazia, South Ossetia |publisher=Rferl.org |date=2006-10-04 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> On 6 March 2008 Russia's Foreign Ministry announced it had lifted sanctions on Abkhazia and called on other CIS member states to do the same. Russia denied the event had any connection to Kosovo, but Georgian parliament speaker [[Nino Burjanadze]] said she believed the move was part of Russia's response to Kosovo's declaration and signals an attempt to "annex" Abkhazia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7282201.stm|title=Russia lifts Abkhazia sanctions|publisher=BBC News|date=2008-03-06|accessdate=2008-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2008/03/E3FD3CDD-6EFC-4DAB-8628-95FECFEF1FEF.html|title=Georgia: Tbilisi Outraged At Moscow Withdrawal From Abkhaz Sanctions Treaty|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe]]|date=2008-03-07|accessdate=2008-03-09 }}</ref>
[[Eduard Kokoity]], the President of South Ossetia's breakaway republic, speaking immediately after Kosovo's secession said, "Some countries will recognise our republics [South Ossetia and Abkhazia]. I cannot rule out that some of them may do so later this year. Russia, however, will not necessarily be the first to recognise our independence."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080220/99703273.html|title=South Ossetia's leader says recognition may come "this year"|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]] (Russia)|date=2008-02-20|accessdate=2008-02-20}}</ref> South Ossetia, Abkhazia, and Transnistria have all submitted formal requests for recognition of their independence to Russia, among other countries, and international organisations citing Kosovo as a precedent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hWgpFUH_fh_-0jPdK-9ZJFj_LgMw |title=Georgia's rebel Abkhazia calls for independence recognition |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (Paris) |date=2008-03-08 |accessdate=2008-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311035015/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hWgpFUH_fh_-0jPdK-9ZJFj_LgMw |archivedate=2008-03-11 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tiraspoltimes.com/node/1616|title=Transnistria asks int'l community for recognition as Europe's newest country|publisher=[[Tiraspol Times]] (Transnistria) |date=2008-02-29|accessdate=2008-03-09}}</ref>
Abkhazia's [[Sergei Bagapsh]] and South Ossetia's Eduard Kokoity said in a statement addressed to the United Nations: "If Kosovo is separated from Serbia and its independence is recognised, one more powerful proof will emerge that ethnic conflicts can be solved on principles other than a respect for territorial integrity ... Abkhazia and South Ossetia have just as strong grounds to demand independence as Kosovo."<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04701612.htm Georgia breakaway provinces eye Kosovo as precedent], ''[[Reuters]]'', June 4, 2007</ref> Separately, Sergey Bagapsh said "The fate of Kosovo has been ordained, thus our fate will also be determined in the nearest future."<ref>[http://www.messenger.com.ge/issues/1412_august_1_2007/n_1412_3.htm Bagapsh: International recognition of Abkhazia sure to follow Kosovo precedent], ''Messenger.ge'', August 1, 2007</ref>
In October 2009, Russian President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] said that parallels between Kosovo and South Ossetia are "inappropriate" and that "We are categorically against drawing parallels between the Balkan events and the events in the Caucasus. As concerns South Ossetia – it’s our unambiguous, absolutely clear position – it about repelling direct military aggression. And what was done by Russia after that, was done in full accordance with the UN Charter." and that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence and the events that followed "have confirmed the inadequacy of attempts to adjust the solution of complex international problems to considerations of notorious political expediency. We consider it unacceptable to do what was done in the Kosovo precedent – to use the lack of progress at negotiations as the reason for unilateral actions, including recognition of new international legal entities." and that the solution to the Kosovo problem should be based upon "the international law, decisions of the UN, resolutions of the UN Security Council and, primarily, Resolution 1244".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.russiatoday.com/Politics/2009-10-20/parallels-kosovo-south-ossetia.html |title=Parallels between Kosovo and South Ossetia "inappropriate" – Medvedev |publisher=Russiatoday.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091024102945/http://www.russiatoday.com/Politics/2009-10-20/parallels-kosovo-south-ossetia.html |archivedate=2009-10-24 |df= }}</ref>
===Armenia, Azerbaijan, Nagorno-Karabakh=== {{stack|[[File:AZ-qa-location-en.svg|thumb|210px|The final borders of the conflict after the 1994 ceasefire was signed.]] }} [[Armenia]]'s Deputy Parliament Speaker Vahan Hovhannisyan has said Kosovo's independence will influence the settlement of the dispute over [[Nagorno-Karabakh]]. [[Foreign Minister]] [[Vardan Oskanyan]] declared at the UN General Assembly session in October 2007 that the Armenian side “does not understand and cannot accept the reverse logic that Kosovo was given independence and that another nation cannot obtain self-determination."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tiraspoltimes.com/news/kosovo_seen_as_precedent_by_four_more_new_countries.html |title=Kosovo seen as precedent by four more new countries |publisher=[[The Tiraspol Times]] (Transnistria) |date=2007-12-17 |accessdate=2007-12-28 }} </ref> Before being elected president, Armenian prime-minister [[Serzh Sargsyan]] said Kosovo was not a precedent for Karabakh. He underlined that Nagorno-Karabakh has been independent for the past 17 years.<ref name="newsru"> {{cite news |script-title=ru:Совбез ООН по требованию России проведет экстренное заседание по Косово. НАТО созывает Совет альянса |url=http://www.newsru.com/world/18feb2008/kosovo.html |publisher=NEWSru.com (Moscow) |date=2008-02-17 |accessdate=2008-02-18 |language=ru }}</ref> However, former President of Armenia [[Robert Kocharyan]] said "The Kosovo precedent is too important for Armenia. Certainly, this will have a positive influence for recognition of independence of Nagorno Karabakh Republic".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.today.az/news/politics/43462.html |title=Robert Kocharyan: "Kosovo may become a precedent for recognition of Nagorno Karabakh's independence" |publisher=Today.az |date=2008-02-29 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref>
An [[Azerbaijan]] Foreign Ministry spokesman has said of Kosovo: "We view this illegal act as being in contradiction with international law."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsMaps/idUSL1856553120080218 |title=Azerbaijan says not recognising Kosovo independence |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 2008-02-18|accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> Following a skirmish between Armenian military forces in Nagorno-Karabakh and Azerbaijan forces which left 4 Azeri and 12 Armenian soldiers dead, Azerbaijan said it was sparked by international recognition of Kosovo. US State Department Spokesman [[Tom Casey (diplomat)|Tom Casey]] rejected the comparison stating "Kosovo is not a precedent and should [not] be seen as a precedent for any other place out there in the world. It certainly isn't a precedent for Nagorno-Karabakh."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/a-13-2008-03-05-voa50.html|title=US Concerned About Fighting in Nagorno-Karabakh|publisher=[[Voice of America News]]|date=2008-03-05|accessdate=2008-03-09}}</ref>
===Moldova and Transnistria=== [[File:Transnistria-map-3.png|thumb|210px|right|Map of Transnistria.]] President of the unrecognised Transdniestrian Moldovan Republic, also known as Transnistria, [[Igor Smirnov]] said that "the Russian leadership, in recognising the independence of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, has underlined the priority of the expression of the wills of the people for solving such problems."
On 27 August, the day after Russia's recognition, [[Dmitry Medvedev]] met with [[President of Moldova]] [[Vladimir Voronin]], where the Russian leader made clear that Moscow is ready to make the maximal efforts to solve the Transnistrian problem in the framework of the sovereignty of the [[Republic of Moldova]]. Relations between Moldova and Transnistria worsened after Moldova refused to support the independence of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, which [[Chişinău]] categorically rejected, considering that "as in the case of the recognition of Kosovo, this step only decreases amenability of the sides in the search for a compromise."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/03sep2008/smirnov.html |title=Медведев встречается с нацеленным на независимость лидером Приднестровья, чтобы урегулировать конфликт |publisher=Newsru.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref>
===Republika Srpska=== {{main|Secession of Republika Srpska}} [[File:BH municipality location.svg|left|thumb|210px|Location of [[Republika Srpska]] (yellow) in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].]]
According to a poll of [[Bosnian Serbs]] taken by the [[Brussels]]-based [[Gallup Balkan Monitor]] in November 2010, 87 percent would support a referendum being called on [[Republika Srpska]]'s independence from [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].<ref name="Srpska">{{cite news|url=http://www.danas.rs/danasrs/svet/region/za_nezavisnu_rs_88_odsto_gradjana.9.html?news_id=204069 |title=Za nezavisnu RS 88 odsto građana -- poll|publisher=Gallup Balkan Monitor|date=2010-11-19}}</ref>
Since Kosovo's declaration of independence Bosnian Serb nationalists have called for Dodik to fulfill his promises and call a referendum. Dodik has since said he will only call a referendum if Srpska's autonomy is threatened.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/8040/ |title=Bosnia's Dodik Calms Secession Fears |publisher=Balkan Insight Reporting Network |work=[[Balkan Insight]] (Bosnia) |date=2008-02-20 |accessdate=2008-02-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226175832/http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/8040/ |archivedate=2008-02-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Despite this Bosnian Serb lawmakers passed a resolution on February 21, 2008 calling for a referendum on independence if a majority of the UN members (97 out of 192), especially members of the European Union, recognise Kosovo's declaration of independence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL22859447 |title=Bosnian Serbs threaten secession over Kosovo|publisher=Reuters (New York City)|date=2008-02-22|accessdate=2008-02-22}}</ref> After the resolution was passed the U.S. cut aid to the [[Alliance of Independent Social Democrats|SNSD]] and the resolution was condemned by the European Union.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pr-inside.com/u-s-cuts-aid-to-main-bosnian-r469759.htm |title=U.S. cuts aid to main Bosnian Serb party |publisher=PR-inside |date=2008-03-04 |accessdate=2008-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210040845/http://www.pr-inside.com/u-s-cuts-aid-to-main-bosnian-r469759.htm |archivedate=February 10, 2012 }}</ref> The [[Peace Implementation Council]] (PIC) overseeing [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] said the country's entities have no right to secede.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/8374/ |title=Bosnia Serb PM Dismisses US Aid Cuts |publisher=Balkan Insight Reporting Network |work=[[Balkan Insight]] (Bosnia) |date=2008-03-05 |accessdate=2008-03-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307045956/http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/8374/ |archivedate=2008-03-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The [[High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Miroslav Lajcak]] said Srpska has "absolutely no right" to secede and that he would use his Bonn Powers "if there are threats to peace and stability" or the Dayton peace agreement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gZyDa4Ekj3nlTBcwlnH93R_2pTOQ|title=Major powers reject Bosnian Serb secession calls|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (Paris)|date=2008-02-27|accessdate=2008-03-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303051918/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gZyDa4Ekj3nlTBcwlnH93R_2pTOQ|archivedate=2008-03-03|df=}}</ref>
In an interview, Dodik said if most countries recognise Kosovo's self-proclaimed independence, this would legitimise the right to secession and added "we do not see a single reason why we should not be granted the right to self-determination, the right envisaged in international conventions."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=09&nav_id=48307|title=Dodik insists RS has right to self-determination|publisher=[[B92]] (Serbia)|work=B92.net/|date=2008-03-09|accessdate=2008-03-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080413235454/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2008&mm=03&dd=09&nav_id=48307|archivedate=2008-04-13|df=}}</ref>
===Montenegro===
Members of the majority in the municipal assembly of [[Pljevlja]] in [[Montenegro]] announced a secession from Montenegro following the Montenegrin recognition of Kosovo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/stories/ci/story/3/%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD/22265/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0+%D0%A6%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B5+%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5+%D0%BE+%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0.html |script-title=sr:Скупштина Црне Горе о демонстрацијама |language=Serbian |publisher=Rts.rs |date=2008-10-15 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref>
===Northern Cyprus=== [[File:Cyprus districts named.png|210px|thumb|right|The northern part areas are administered by Turkish Cypriots.]] Ozdil Nami, a senior [[Turkish Cypriot]] official, told the ''[[Turkish Daily News]]'', "When diplomatic efforts are exhausted other alternatives are put on the table. We clearly see this in Kosovo where diplomacy proved futile and other formulas are floating around. This will certainly have an impact on Cyprus."<ref name="TurkCyprus">{{cite news|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/world-article.php?yyyy=2007&mm=12&dd=27&nav_id=46506|title=Turkish paper: North Cyprus eyes Kosovo outcome|publisher=[[B92]] ([[Belgrade]])|work=b92.net/|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080106150818/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/world-article.php?yyyy=2007&mm=12&dd=27&nav_id=46506|archivedate=2008-01-06|df=}}</ref> Nami suggests the resolution of Kosovo may be applied to [[North Cyprus]] well. According to Nami, "Everyone sees 2008 as the last window of opportunity for a solution to the Cyprus problem." He claims Cyprus is being warned that "other alternatives could be on the agenda" if there is no resolution.<ref name=TurkCyprus/> Turkish Cypriot leader [[Mehmet Ali Talat]] has rejected this connection saying "We do not see a direct link between the situation in Kosovo and the Cyprus Problem. These problems have come up through different conditions."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newkosovareport.com/20080329814/Views-and-Analysis/A-united-Cyprus-first-fruit-of-Kosovo-s-independence.html|title=A united Cyprus: first fruit of Kosovo's independence?|publisher=New Kosova Report|date=2008-03-29|accessdate=2008-03-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080403014449/http://www.newkosovareport.com/20080329814/Views-and-Analysis/A-united-Cyprus-first-fruit-of-Kosovo-s-independence.html|archivedate=2008-04-03|df=}}</ref>
=== Slovakia === In [[Slovakia]] the Kosovo precedent is seen as a potential threat to its territorial integrity because of the worsened relations with the ethnic [[Hungarians in Slovakia|Hungarians]] that live on the south of the country.<ref>{{cite book|title=International Affairs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mNAMAQAAMAAJ|year=2008|publisher=Znanye Publishing House|page=152|quote=During the last year or two years, relations between the leadership of Slovakia and the native ethnic Hungarians, who live in close-knit communities in the country's south, have worsened once again, for which reason the Kosovo precedent is viewed in Slovakia as a potential treat to territorial integrity of the comparatively young Slovak state.}}</ref>
=== Macedonia === {{further|Republic of Ilirida}} Since the [[2001 insurgency in the Republic of Macedonia]], there has been several terrorist incidents in the Republic of Macedonia involving Albanian militants. In 2012 there was some [[2012 Republic of Macedonia inter-ethnic violence|civil unrest]]. The [[Smilkovci lake killings]] (12 April 2012), [[2014 Macedonian government building attack|government rocket attack]] (28 October 2014), [[Gošince attack]] (21 April 2015) and [[Kumanovo clashes]] (9–10 May 2015) were claimed by the [[National Liberation Army (Albanians of Macedonia)|National Liberation Army]], which gave the message that "We do not want any [[Ohrid Agreement|framework agreement]] and if we see you here again, we will kill you. We want [[Republic of Ilirida|our own state]]."<ref name=B92>{{cite news|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2015&mm=04&dd=21&nav_category=167&nav_id=983125|title=MKD: Teroristi OVK upali u karaulu|date=21 April 2015|publisher=B92|id=983125|language=sr}}</ref>
===Palestine=== {{see also|Palestinian self-determination}} On 20 February 2008, days following Kosovo's declaration of independence, Yasser Abed Rabbo, the top aid to President Mahmoud Abbas declared that Palestine should unilaterally announce its independence in a similar manner. Israel has criticized states that have recognized Palestine but refuse to recognize Kosovo, stating that Israel will not recognize Kosovo until all European states do so.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/israel-to-recognize-kosovo-only-after-eu|title= Israel Dismisses Talk of Recognizing Kosovo|publisher=Balkan Insight}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.brusselsjournal.com/node/3039|title=The Kosovo Precedent|publisher=The Business Journal}}</ref>
===Catalonia=== {{further|Catalan independence}} Russian diplomat [[Konstantin Kosachev]] said that granting Kosovo independence against the suzerainty of Serbia has opened [[wikt:Pandora's box|Pandora's box]], but prognosed that Catalonia would remain a part of Spain after the [[Catalan independence referendum, 2017|referendum]].<ref name="b92.net"/>
==North Kosovo== {{main|North Kosovo}} [[File:North_Kosovo_blank_map.png|thumb|Map highlighting North Kosovo municipalities.]] Since the independence declaration, the Serb-inhabited [[North Kosovo]], through its municipalities and subsequently the [[Community of Serb Municipalities|Assembly of the Community of Municipalities]], was ''de facto'' independent during the [[North Kosovo crisis]], until the [[Brussels Agreement (2013)]]. In 2012, [[North Kosovo referendum, 2012|a referendum]] saw 99.74% of voters reject the Republic of Kosovo. A planned [[Community of Serb Municipalities]] is set to be formed.
==See also== * [[Nationalism]] * [[Colour revolution]] * [[Greater Albania]] * [[Irredentism]] * [[Kosovo status process]] * [[Yugoslav Wars]] * [[Controversy over Abkhazian and South Ossetian independence]]
{{-}} ==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Jia, Bing Bing. "The independence of Kosovo: A unique case of secession?." Chinese Journal of International Law 8.1 (2009): 27-46. *Allin, Dana H. "Unintended consequences–managing Kosovo independence." What Status for Kosovo (2001): 7-17. *Charney, Jonathan I. "Self-Determination: Chechnya, Kosovo, and East Timor." Vand. J. Transnatl. L. 34 (2001): 455. *Nevo, Zohar, and Tamar Megiddo. "Lessons From Kosovo: The Law of Statehood and Palestinian Unilateral Independence." J. Int'l L & Int'l Rel. 5 (2009): 89. *Faulconbridge, Guy, March MOSCOW, and South Ossetia. "Georgia rebel region seeks recognition after Kosovo." Reuters (2008). *Müllerson, Rein. "Precedents in the mountains: on the parallels and uniqueness of the cases of Kosovo, South Ossetia and Abkhazia." Chinese Journal of International Law 8.1 (2009): 2-25. *Berg, Eiki. "Re-examining sovereignty claims in changing territorialities: reflections from ‘Kosovo Syndrome’." Geopolitics 14.2 (2009): 219-234. *McNamara, Sally. "Russia’s Recognition of Independence for South Ossetia and Abkhazia Is Illegitimate: They Are Not Kosovo." Heritage Foundation WebMemo 2037 (2008): 28. *Summers, James, ed. Kosovo: A Precedent?: The Declaration of Independence, the Advisory Opinion and Implications for Statehood, Self-Determination and Minority Rights. Brill, 2011. *Borgen, Christopher J. "From Kosovo to Catalonia: Separatism and Integration in Europe." Goettingen J. Int'l L. 2 (2010): 997.

{{Infobox University |name = Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies |native_name = Latvijas Lauksaimniecības universitāte |image_name = Latvia_University_of_Agriculture_logo.png |image_upright = |caption = |latin_name = |former_names = Jelgava Academy of Agriculture (1936–1944),
Latvia Academy of Agriculture (1944–1990)
Latvia University of Agriculture (1990–2018) |motto = ''Proventus pro patria'' |mottoeng = For the Growth of the Fatherland{{cite web |url = https://www.pasts.lv/en/footer/Useful_Information/News/philately_news/2075-stamp-dedicated-to-150th-anniversary-of-latvia-university-of-agriculture-to-be-presented-in-ceremony |title = Stamp dedicated to 150th anniversary of Latvia University of Agriculture to be presented in ceremony |date= September 12, 2013|author=Zane Plone |publisher = [[Latvijas Pasts]] |accessdate = 2016-05-07}} |established = 1938 |type = Public |endowment = |rector = Irina Pilvere |staff = 354 |students = 4778 (2013) |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = 186 (2013) |city = [[Jelgava]] |country = [[Latvia]] |campus = |colours = {{color box|yellow}}{{color box|green}}{{color box|brown}} [[Yellow]], [[white]] and [[brown]] |nickname = |website = http://www.llu.lv |logo = |logo_size = }} The '''Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies''' (until March 6, 2018 – '''Latvia University of Agriculture''' ('''LLU'''); {{lang-lv|Latvijas Lauksaimniecības universitāte}}; ''LLU''){{cite web |url = http://www.llu.lv/en/article/2018-03-06/latvia-university-of-agriculture-changes-its-name-to-latvia-university-of-life |title = Latvia University of Agriculture changes its name to Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies |date=May 6, 2018 |publisher = Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies |accessdate = 2018-03-07}} is a university in [[Jelgava]], [[Latvia]], specializing in [[agricultural science]], [[forestry]], [[food technology]] and related areas. == History == The university originated as the Agricultural Department at the [[Riga Polytechnical Institute]] in 1863, which in 1919 became the Faculty of Agriculture at the [[University of Latvia]].{{cite book |author = [[United Nations Economic Commission for Europe]] |title = Latvia: Towards a Knowledge-Based Economy |publisher = United Nations |year = 2002 |page = 23 |isbn = 92-1-116822-8}} It became an independent institution in 1939, when it was established as the Academy of Agriculture in the [[Jelgava Palace]], which had been renovated for that purpose.{{cite web |url = http://eng.llu.lv/?mi=579 |title = The Jelgava palace throughout the centuries |publisher = Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies |accessdate = 2011-03-09}} It was renamed to the Latvia University of Agriculture in 1990 and Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies on March 6, 2018. ==Organisation== [[File:Jelgava Palace viewed from the courtyard.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jelgava Palace]], the administrative centre of the university]] The university consists of 8 faculties offering the following study programmes:[http://www.llu.lv/en/structure Latvian University of Life Sciences and Technologies: Structure] * Faculty of Economics and Social Development (2013) :*Economics :*Business Studies :*Entrepreneurship and Business Management :*Business Management :*Financial Management * Faculty of Information Technologies (2001) :*Computer Control and Computer Science :*Programming :*Information Technologies * Faculty of Agriculture (1863) :*Agriculture :*Agricultural Entrepreneurship :*Agronomist with Specialization in Zootechnics :*Field Crops :*Horticulture * Faculty of Environment and Civil Engineering (1947) :*Civil Engineering and Construction :*Land Surveying and Management :*Environmental Science :*Landscape Architecture :*Landscape Architecture and Planning :*Water Management :*Environement and Water Management :*Environmental Engineering * Forest Faculty (1920) :*Forestry Science :*Forest Ecology and Silviculture :*Forest Works and Machinery :*Forest Economics and Policy :*Wood Materials and Technology :*Forestry :*Wood Processing Technology :*Wood Processing :*Labour Safety :*Forest Engineering * [[Faculty of Food Technology, Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies|Faculty of Food Technology]] (1948) :*Food Science :*Nutrition Science :*Catering and Hotel Management :*Food Technology * Faculty of Engineering (1944) :*Agricultural Engineering :*Technical Expert :*Agricultural Power Engineering :*Machine Design and Manufacturing :*Home Environment in Education :*Teacher of Vocational Education :*Pedagogy :*Career Counsellor * Faculty of Veterinary Medicine (1919) :*Veterinary Medicine :*Food Hygiene ==Rectors== *Pāvils Kvelde ([[:lv:Pāvils Kvelde|lv]]) (1939–1940, 1941–1944) *Pauls Galenieks ([[:lv:Pauls Galenieks|lv]]) (1940–1941) *Jānis Ostrovs (1941) *Maksis Eglītis ([[:lv:Maksis Eglītis|lv]]) (1944) *[[Jānis Peive]] (1944–1950) *Amālija Cekuliņa (1950–1954) *Jānis Vanags ([[:lv:Jānis Vanags|lv]]) (1954–1961) *Pāvils Zariņš (1961–1966) *Olģerts Ozols (1966–1976) *Kazimirs Špoģis ([[:lv:Kazimirs Špoģis|lv]]) (1976–1980) *Viktors Timofejevs (1980–1986) *Imants Gronskis (1986–1992) *Voldemārs Strīķis ([[:lv:Voldemārs Strīķis|lv]]) (1992–2002) *Pēteris Bušmanis (2002–2004) *Juris Skujāns (2004–2014) *Irina Pilvere (2014–present) ==Notable alumni== * [[Andris Šķēle]] – [[Prime Minister of Latvia]] and industurialist * [[Aigars Kalvītis]] – Prime Minister of Latvia and CEO of [[Latvijas Gāze]] * [[Roberts Zīle]] – [[Member of the European Parliament]] and co-chairman of the [[National Alliance (Latvia)|National Alliance]] * [[Atis Slakteris]] – [[List of Ministers of Defence of Latvia|Minister of Defence of Latvia]] * [[Andris Ārgalis]] – [[Mayor of Riga]] * [[Uldis Sesks]] – Mayor of [[Liepāja]] and chairman of the [[Liepāja Special Economic Zone]] * [[Jānis Urbanovičs]] – member of the [[Saeima]] and chairman of the [[Social Democratic Party "Harmony"|Harmony]] party * [[Vilnis Edvīns Bresis]] – last Premier of the Soviet régime in Latvia, voted for the [[On the Restoration of Independence of the Republic of Latvia|renewed declaration of independence]] * [[Jānis Dūklavs]] – Minister of Agriculture of Latvia * [[Dzintars Jaundžeikars]] – Minister of the Interior of Latvia * [[Dace Reinika]] – Member of the Saeima and Mayor of [[Tērvete Municipality|Tērvete]] ==Gallery== File:Faculty_of_Food_Technology,_Latvia_University_of_Agriculture.JPG|[[Faculty of Food Technology, Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies|Faculty of Food Technology]] File:Jelgava, Svētes iela 18.jpg|Faculty of Economics and Social Development on Svētes Street File:Vecauce Manor.jpg|[[Vecauce Manor]] research farm ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies}} * [http://eng.llu.lv/ Official site] {{en icon}} {{coord|56|40|01|N|23|45|37|E|region:LV_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}} {{Latvian universities}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Latvia University of Life Sciences and Technologies| ]] [[Category:Universities in Latvia]] {{latvia-university-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox bridge| |bridge_name= The Mala Rijeka Viaduct |image= Mala Rijeka Viaduct.JPG |official_name=Мост изнад Мале Ријеке/Most iznad Male Rijeke |location=Mala Rijeka River, Montenegro |designer=Ljubomir Jevtovic (Engineers: Milivoje Kovacevic, Milorad Lukovic and Milorad Markovic) |material= Steel, concrete |carries=1 rail track |crosses=Valley of the Mala Rijeka River |builder=[[Mostogradnja]] |begin=1969<ref name=structurae>{{Structurae|id=s0006003|name=Mala Rijeka Bridge}}</ref> |complete=1973<ref name=structurae /> |open= 1973 |design=[[Truss bridge]] |mainspan={{convert|150.8|m|0|abbr=on}} |length={{convert|498.8|m|0|abbr=on}} |height= {{convert|139|m|0|abbr=on}} |below= {{convert|198|m|0|abbr=on}} |coordinates= {{Coord|42|33|09|N|19|23|15|E|}} }} The '''Mala Rijeka Viaduct''' is a viaduct on the [[Belgrade–Bar railway]], located some 20 km north of [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]].
== Overview == [[File:Wiadukt kolejowy Mala Rijeka w Czarnogórze.JPG|thumb|left|250px|The Mala Rijeka Viaduct seen from the train]] <nowiki>The project was started in 1969 and was completed in 1973. The viaduct is </nowiki>{{convert|498.8|m|ft}} long and at its highest is {{convert|200|m|ft}} above the ''Mala Rijeka'' ({{IPA-sh|mâːlaː rijɛ̌ka|pron}}, meaning literally ''Little river''). It is also the longest bridge on the Belgrade–Bar railway.<ref>[http://www.serbiaconstruction.com/projects/the-mala-rijeka-bridge/ Serbia Construction The Mala Rijeka bridge]</ref>
When constructed it was the highest railway bridge in the world, surpassing the record height previously held by the [[Fades viaduct]] in France. It held the record until 2001 when the [[Beipan River Shuibai Railway Bridge]], a concrete arch bridge, was completed in Guizhou, China. Multiple railway bridges under construction in China will also be higher.<ref>[http://www.highestbridges.com/wiki/index.php?title=Mala_Rijeka_Viaduct Mala Rijeka Viaduct at HighestBridges.Com]</ref>
== Construction == 36,000 m³ of [[concrete]] and 100,000 [[tonne]]s{{Citation needed|date=April 2018|reason=citation needed to credibilise the weight values}} of steel were built into the bridge. The largest of four pillars, upon which the bridge lies, has a base bigger than a [[tennis court]].
Belgian [[extreme sport]]sman Cedric Dumont was the first person ever to [[BASE jumping|jump]] from the bridge on 11 September 2008.
== See also == * [[List of tallest bridges]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{Structurae|id=s0006003|title=Mala Rijeka Bridge}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pPr4uVSd4jA Cedric Dumont base jumping from the viaduct]

revision.text:
{{infobox book | | name = Rapture for the Geeks:
When AI Outsmarts IQ | image = Rapture for the Geeks.jpg| caption = | author = [[Richard Dooling]] | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | publisher = [[Crown_Publishing_Group|Crown]] | release_date = September 30, 2008 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]]) | pages = 272 | isbn = 978-0307405258 }} '''''Rapture for the Geeks: When AI Outsmarts IQ''''' (2009) is a non-fiction book by American [[Law Professor]] [[Richard Dooling]]. The book provides an alarming{{cite news|title="Rapture for the Geeks": Hello, Hal? The past and future of technology|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/books/2008299229_br26geek.html|accessdate=15 June 2014|publisher=[[Seattle Times]]|date=23 October 2008}} window into a hypothetical future [[technological singularity]], where machine intelligence outstrips human intelligence.{{cite news|title=BOOKS: Author tells how Hitler grew into a monster who orchestrated unthinkable horrors|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/arts/index.ssf/2009/01/books_author_tells_how_hitler.html|accessdate=15 June 2014|publisher=[[The Star-Ledger]]|quote=[T]his book explores the history of computers to date -- and ponders the possibilities that will emerge when they become more intelligent than humans.}} The book also provides a historical review of man's relationship with machines,{{cite news|title=Rapture for the Geeks: When AI Outsmarts IQ|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-307-40525-8|accessdate=15 June 2014|publisher=[[Publishers Weekly]]|date=25 August 2008}} including dangers caused by other technologies such as nuclear weaponry. ==See also== * [[Technological singularity]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2008 books]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence publications]] [[Category:Futurology books]] [[Category:Existential risk]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Undervud
Ундервуд | image = Ундервуд 1.jpg | caption = | image_size = 220 | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Simferopol]], [[Ukraine]] | genre = rock | years_active = 1995- | label = | associated_acts = | website = Official Website http://www.undervud.ru/ | current_members = Maksym Kucherenko, Volodymyr Tkachenko | past_members = }}{{commons category|Undervud}} '''Undervud''' ({{lang-ru|Ундервуд}}, Russian spelling of ''[[Underwood_Typewriter_Company|Underwood]]'') is a [[Russia]]n and [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] [[musical group]] (alternative rock, indie rock style) established by Maksim Kucherenko (Максим Кучеренко) and Vladimir Tkachenko (Владимир Ткаченко), two medical students from the [[Crimea]]. The group locates in Moscow and has the reputation of being loved all around the former Soviet Union. They released 8 albums, last one – in September 2015. The soundtracks of the group are used in several films, cartoons and theatrical performances. The band’s songs are present in the charts of radio stations in Russia and other post-Soviet countries and are also aired by some overseas stations (Israel, United States). Their albums occupy the top places in the final year charts. Undervud is the winner of several musical nominations, among them the Russian “Baker’s dozen” (“Best Album”), “Steppenwolf” (“Best Lyrics” and “Best Song”), Rock Alternative Music Prize and “Song of the Year” (“The most beautiful girl in the world”), according to the radio station Jam FM. Undervud has always been loved by journalists, editors, writers and poets. Undervud is the winner of the International Voloshin Prize “for aesthetics in contemporary music and poetic lyrics”. It is the first musical group to receive such a high praise from the literary community. == Discography == * ''Vse proydet, milaya'' (''Everything Will Pass by, Darling''), 2002 * ''Krasnaya Knopka'' (''Red Button''), 2003 * ''Bablo pobezhdaet zlo'' (''Money Conquers the Evil''), 2005 * ''Opium dlya naroda'' (''Opium for People''), 2007 * ''Vse, kogo ty tak sil'no lyubil'' (''Everyone That You Used to Love So Much''), 2008 * ''Babl-gam'' (''Bubble Gum''), 2011 * ''Women & kids'', 2013 * ''Out of borders'', 2015 == External links== * http://www.undervud.ru/ Official site {{Authority control}} [[Category:Russian rock music groups]] {{Asia-band-stub}} {{russia-stub}}
